column1: TA2.11;The amount of renewable fuels and renewable electricity supplied to the transport sector leads to a: (i) share of renewable energy within the final consumption of energy in the transport sector of at least 29 % by 2030; or (ii) GHG intensity reduction of at least 14.5 % by 2030
column2: compared to the baseline set out in Article 27(1)
column3: in accordance with an indicative trajectory set by the Member State.;TA5.32;+;The implementation of TA2.11 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.32
column4: as increasing the share of renewable energy in the transport sector can lead to a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution
column5: which in turn can improve food security and access to quality

column1: TA2.13;The amount of renewable fuels and renewable electricity supplied to the transport sector leads to a: (i) share of renewable energy within the final consumption of energy in the transport sector of at least 29 % by 2030; or (ii) GHG intensity reduction of at least 14.5 % by 2030
column2: compared to the baseline set out in Article 27(1)
column3: in accordance with an indicative trajectory set by the Member State.;TA6.1;+;The implementation of TA2.13 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.1
column4: as reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the transport sector can contribute to the protection of biodiversity and ecosystems
column5: which is essential for achieving the target of protecting at least 30% of the EU's land area.

column1: TA2.14;Member States shall ensure that at least 3% of the total floor area of heated and/or cooled buildings (of buildings which have a total useful floor area of over 250 m2 and are not nearly-zero energy buildings) that are owned by public bodies is renovated each year to be transformed into at least nearly zero-energy buildings or zero-emission buildings;TA2.25;+;The implementation of TA2.14 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.25
column2: as renovating public buildings to achieve nearly zero-energy or zero-emission status can contribute to reducing buildings' final energy consumption
column3: which is a key objective of TA2.25.

column2: achieve 18% of the total increase in the share of energy from renewable sources between that Member State’s binding 2020 national target
column3: and its contribution to the 2030 target of the share of energy from renewable sources in gross final consumption of energy.;TA6.7;+;The implementation of TA2.15 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.7
column4: as increasing the share of renewable energy can contribute to the restoration of degraded and carbon-rich ecosystems
column5: which is essential for achieving the target of restoring significant areas of degraded ecosystems.

column1: TA2.16;Member States shall endeavour to increase the share of renewable sources in the amount of energy sources used for final energy and non-energy purposes in the industry sector by an indicative increase of at least 1.6 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the periods 2021 to 2025 and 2026 to 2030;TA2.22;+;The implementation of TA2.16 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.22
column2: as increasing the share of renewable energy in the industry sector can contribute to reducing energy consumption
column3: which is a key objective of TA2.22.

column1: TA2.17;A target of 15% electricity interconnection for 2030;TA2.23;+;The implementation of TA2.17 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.23
column2: as increasing electricity interconnection can contribute to reducing primary energy consumption
column3: which is a key objective of TA2.23.

column1: TA2.21;Member States shall ensure that the total final energy consumption of all public bodies combined is reduced by at least 1.9% each year
column2: when compared to 2021;TA2.24;+;The implementation of TA2.21 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.24
column3: as reducing energy consumption in public bodies can contribute to achieving the target of renovating at least 3% of the total floor area of heated and/or cooled buildings owned by public bodies each year.

column1: TA2.22;Member States shall collectively ensure a reduction of energy consumption of at least 11.7% in 2030 compared to the projections of the 2020 EU Reference Scenario;TA5.33;-;The implementation of TA2.22 may have a negative impact on TA5.33
column2: as reducing energy consumption can lead to increased food prices and reduced access to nutritious food

column1: TA2.23;Member States shall make efforts to collectively contribute to the indicative Union primary energy consumption target amounting to no more than 992.5 Mtoe in 2030;TA6.10;+;The implementation of TA2.23 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.10
column2: as reducing primary energy consumption can contribute to achieving the target of reducing pollution and protecting the environment.

column1: TA2.24;Each Member State shall ensure that at least 3% of the total floor area of heated and/or cooled buildings (of buildings which have a total useful floor area of over 250 m2 and are not nearly-zero energy buildings) that are owned by public bodies is renovated each year to be transformed into at least nearly zero-energy buildings or zero-emission buildings;TA2.26;+;The implementation of TA2.24 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.26
column2: as renovating public buildings can contribute to increasing the annual energy renovation rate of residential and non-residential buildings.

column1: TA2.25;Reduce buildings’ final energy consumption by 14%;TA2.28;+;The implementation of TA2.25 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.28
column2: as reducing buildings' final energy consumption can contribute to reducing energy consumption for heating and cooling.

column1: TA2.26;At least double the annual energy renovation rate of residential and non-residential buildings by 2030 and to foster deep energy renovations;TA2.34;+;The implementation of TA2.26 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.34
column2: as increasing the annual energy renovation rate can contribute to reducing the average primary energy use of the entire residential building stock.

column1: TA2.28;Reduce buildings’ energy consumption for heating and cooling by 18% compared to 2015 levels by 2030;TA5.34;-;The implementation of TA2.28 may have a negative impact on TA5.34
column2: as reducing energy consumption for heating and cooling can lead to increased food prices and reduced access to nutritious food

column1: TA2.29;Member states will have to renovate 16% of worst-performing non-residential buildings by 2030 and
column3: the worst-performing 26% through minimum energy performance requirements;TA2.37;+;The implementation of TA2.29 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.37
column4: as renovating non-residential buildings can contribute to achieving the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the building sector.

column1: TA2.33;The national measures will have to ensure that at least 55% of the decrease of the average primary energy use is achieved through the renovation of the worst-performing buildings;TA2.41;+;The implementation of TA2.33 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.41
column2: as renovating worst-performing buildings can contribute to achieving the target of reducing end-use energy savings.

column1: TA2.34;Member States shall ensure that the average primary energy use of the entire residential building stock decreases by at least 16% compared to 2020 by 2030;TA2.37;+;The implementation of TA2.34 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.37
column2: as reducing primary energy use in residential buildings can contribute to achieving the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the building sector.
the share of renewable energy in the electricity mix should double to 55-60%
column3: and projections show a share of around 84% by 2050. The remaining gap should be covered by other low-carbon options;TA6.1;+;The implementation of TA2.37 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.1
column4: as increasing the share of renewable energy in the electricity mix can contribute to protecting biodiversity and ecosystems.

column1: TA2.41;Member States are required to achieve cumulative end-use energy savings from 2021 to 2030
column2: equivalent to new annual savings of at least 0.8% of final energy consumption in 2021-2023
column4: 1.5% in 2026-2027 and 1.9% in 2028-2030;TA2.22;+;The implementation of TA2.41 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.22
column5: as achieving cumulative end-use energy savings can contribute to reducing energy consumption.

column1: TA5.32;Food security: Ensuring food security and access to quality
column2: safe
column4: nutritious food for all.;TA2.11;+;The implementation of TA5.32 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.11
column5: as ensuring food security and access to quality food can contribute to increasing the share of renewable energy in the transport sector.

column1: TA5.33;Nutrition and healthy
column2: sustainable diets: Move to healthier and more sustainable diets;TA2.22;-;The implementation of TA5.33 may have a negative impact on TA2.22
column3: as moving to healthier and more sustainable diets can lead to increased energy consumption and reduced access to affordable food options.

column1: TA5.34;Health impact of diets: Reversing of the rise in overweight and obesity rates across the EU by 2030;TA2.28;-;The implementation of TA5.34 may have a negative impact on TA2.28
column2: as reversing the rise in overweight and obesity rates can lead to increased energy consumption for heating and cooling.

column1: TA5.35;Preparedness
column2: shock resilience
column3: adaptation and transformation: Strengthen the resilience of the EU food system;TA2.23;+;The implementation of TA5.35 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.23
column4: as strengthening the resilience of the EU food system can contribute to reducing primary energy consumption.

column1: TA6.1;1.a Legally protect a minimum of 30% of the EU’s land area;TA2.13;+;The implementation of TA6.1 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.13
column2: as protecting a minimum of 30% of the EU's land area can contribute to reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the transport sector.

column1: TA6.2;1.b Legally protect a minimum of 30% of the EU's sea area;TA2.17;+;The implementation of TA6.2 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.17

significant areas of degraded and carbon-rich ecosystems are restored;TA2.15;+;The implementation of TA6.7 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.15
